o: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing. Mechanism allowing browser to load resources from different origin
Combination of Scheme (Protocol), Host (Domain), and Port
Same-Origin Policy. Browser security model preventing scripts from one origin accessing data of another

q: Does SOP block loading images from other origins?
o: Generally No. You can embed images (embedding is allowed, reading pixel data is blocked unless CORS)

q: Does SOP block `fetch()` or XHR to other origins?
o: Yes. Unless the server sends correct CORS headers

q: What header allows access from specific origin?
What allows access from ANY origin?

o: Request (GET/HEAD/POST) with limited headers/content-types that doesn't trigger Preflight

q: What Content-Types are allowed in Simple Request?

o: Yes. It is not a simplified content-type
An OPTIONS request sent by browser automatically before the actual request to check permissions

q: What HTTP method is used for Preflight?
What status code should Preflight return?
What header lists allowed methods in Preflight response?
What header lists allowed headers in Preflight response?

o: Cache duration (in seconds) for the Preflight response
To avoid sending OPTIONS request for every single API call (Performance)
Header (true) allowing browser to send cookies/auth headers with the request
No. If Credentials are true, Origin CANNOT be *. It must be specific

q: What happens if server sends `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *` AND `Allow-Credentials: true`?
How to support multiple origins with Credentials?
o: Server checks `Origin` header dynamically and reflects it back in `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` if whitelisted

q: What header does Browser send to indicate origin?

o: No. It is a forbidden header controlled by browser
Lists headers that browser script is allowed to read from response (e.g. `X-Custom-Token`)

q: Which headers are exposed by default in CORS response?
o: Simple headers: Cache-Control, Content-Language, Content-Type, Expires, Last-Modified, Pragma

q: Is `Set-Cookie` exposed to JS via CORS?
o: No. `Set-Cookie` is filtered out for security (HttpOnly logic applies)
Sends request but gives opaque response (can't read body/status). Useful for logging/tracking pixels only
Response where JS can't see content, status code, or headers (status appears as 0)

q: Can you load a Font from another origin?
o: Only if server allows via CORS. Fonts often enforce CORS even for GET

q: Can you load a Script (`<script src=...>`) from another origin?
o: Yes. Scripts are embeddable resources (not subject to SOP for execution, but reading code might be)
Tells browser to use CORS. Allows receiving detailed error details in `window.onerror` instead of 'Script Error'
Browser blocks the actual request. It is never sent
Actual request is sent anyway but ignored
Yes. CORS is a Browser restriction. `curl`/Postman don't enforce it
Server often replies with headers. It's the CLIENT (Browser) that sees headers and decides to block JS access
Tells caching proxies that response differs based on Origin. Crucial when dynamically reflecting Access-Control-Allow-Origin

q: What happens if you miss `Vary: Origin` when reflecting origin?
o: Cache poisoning. Example.com response might be cached and served to Evil.com (or vice versa blocking legit users)
Allowing arbitary origins (reflecting Origin header blindly) + Allow Credentials. Opens up data theft
Origin sent by local files (`file://`) or sandboxed iframes. Can be exploitable if `null` is whitelisted
Often needed for local development (opening HTML file directly). Dangerous in prod
Header sent by Browser in Preflight asking 'Can I use this method?'
Header sent by Browser in Preflight asking 'Can I send these headers?'

q: Does a simple GET request need CORS to read response?
o: Yes. Browser sends request, but if response lacks `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`, Browser destroys response body so JS can't see it

q: Does `` allow JS to read pixel data?
o: No (SOP). Unless `crossorigin` attribute used + server sends CORS header. (Canvas tainting)
If you draw non-CORS image to Canvas, canvas becomes 'tainted'. `toDataURL()`/`getImageData()` throws error
Prevent reading private images (captchas, banking charts) loaded from other origins
Yes. Browsers treat localhost as secure (like https) for development
No. WebSockets differ. Browser sends Origin, server must validate it. But SOP doesn't block handshake strictly like fetch
Server receives `Origin` header in handshake. Server chooses to accept/reject connection (CSWSH protection)
Cross-Site WebSocket Hijacking. Like CSRF but for WebSockets

q: Does CORS apply to Server-Sent Events (SSE)?
o: Yes. `EventSource` follows CORS rules (requires Allow-Origin header)

q: What is the max value for `Access-Control-Max-Age` in Chrome?
o: 600 seconds (10 minutes) or 7200 (2 hours) depending on version cap. (Spec allows more, browsers cap it)
Proposed header for CORS-RFC1918 (Private Network Access) checks
Protecting internal devices (routers/printers) from being accessed by public internet websites via browser

q: Can you disable CORS in browser?
o: Yes, via flags or extensions (e.g. `--disable-web-security`). Only for dev/testing!
Headers allowed in Simple Requests (Accept, Accept-Language, Content-Language, Content-Type)
Server that fetches resource and adds `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *` to response. (e.g. `cors-anywhere`)

q: Is using a public CORS proxy safe for production?
o: No. Slow, unreliable, and privacy risk (proxy sees traffic)

q: How to fix CORS error locally?
o: Configure your local dev server (Vite/Webpack) to proxy API requests or add headers
Dev server forwards `/api` requests to backend. Browser sees same-origin request to dev server. (Bypasses CORS during dev)

q: Why do mobile apps (native) not have CORS issues?
o: They are not browsers. They don't enforce SOP. They can request any URL
No. CORS is a Browser concept

q: What is the 'SameSite' cookie attribute relation to CORS?
o: Orthogonal. SameSite controls cookie sending on cross-site requests (CSRF). CORS controls response reading
No. JSONP (JSON with Padding) is a workaround using `<script>` tags to bypass SOP before CORS existed
Generally No. Vulnerable to XSS (evaluating arbitrary script code)
CSP (Content Security Policy) restricts where browser can load resources FROM. CORS restricts who can read resources

q: If CSP blocks a domain, does CORS matter?
o: No. CSP blocks the request before CORS logic even happens
Controls what is sent in `Referer` header.
`strict-origin-when-cross-origin` (Sends origin only, no path, on cross-origin HTTPS)
Server might check it, but `Origin` is the primary header for CORS checks

q: Can you wildcard subdomains in CORS config?
o: Spec says No for `Allow-Origin`. Must be full origin or `*`. (Servers implement wildcard logic dynamically)
Server logic: regex match Origin header, if matches, echo it back in Allow-Origin
Resource Timing API header allowing JS to see detailed timing (DNS, TCP start) of external resource

q: Does sending OPTIONS manually with JS trigger Preflight logic?
o: No. It's just a regular fetch request with method OPTIONS. Real Preflight is internal to browser
Browsers don't cache 0/Error response content, but might remember Preflight failure for short time
If CORS request is redirected, the redirect response AND final response must both pass CORS checks

q: Does `Location` header expose redirect URL to JS?
o: No, opaque by default unless exposed? Actually `fetch` follows redirects automatically. `manual` mode returns opaque
Header requesting permission to access local network device from public web
No. It allows public access or controlled access. It relies on Cookies/Tokens for actual user auth

q: Can you use CORS to prevent bot scraping?
o: No. Bots (Python, curl) ignore CORS headers. CORS protects USERS (browsers)
Browser throws CORS error: 'No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present'
Not allowed. Must be single value (or null/star). Spec forbids list
Partially. Preflights prevent some CSRF (PUT/DELETE/JSON). But Simple Requests (POST Form) still go through! (Need Anti-CSRF tokens)
Yes. It is a Simple Request

q: Can attacker send JSON via `text/plain` POST?
o: Yes. Body is valid JSON, but Content-Type is text/plain. Server might parse it anyway (CSRF risk)
Enforce Content-Type check on server. Require `application/json` (which prompts Preflight)
Headers that don't trigger preflight: Accept, Accept-Language, Content-Language, Content-Type (parsed values)
It was removed/deprecated? Usually considered safe or forbidden to set by JS

q: Can you use CORS with 'file://' scheme?
o: Spec is vague. Chrome blocks 'file://' AJAX by default (security). Firefox has looser rules. Run a local server!
Cross-Origin Read Blocking. Algorithm to identify/block sensitive data (HTML/JSON/XML) from entering process memory via ``/`
Cross-Origin Resource Policy. Header (`Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy`) allowing resource to opt-in/out of being loaded by others
Cross-Origin Embedder Policy. Header (`require-corp`) ensuring that all resources loaded by page explicitly opt-in via CORP or CORS
Cross-Origin Opener Policy. Header isolating the browsing context (window) from other origins (prevents Spectre attacks via shared process)
To enable 'Cross-Origin Isolated' state, which unlocks powerful features like `SharedArrayBuffer` and `performance.now()` high-res

q: What is 'Spectre' mitigation in CORS context?
o: Browsers limit high-res timers and SharedArrayBuffer unless site is Cross-Origin Isolated (COOP+COEP)
Private Network Access. Still evolving (Chrome warns, plans to block public->private without Preflight)
Header requesting PNA permission during Preflight

q: How to debug CORS in Chrome DevTools?
o: Network Tab -> Click Request -> Headers. Look for 'CORS error' status or missing response headers

q: What does 'Response to preflight request doesn't pass access control check' mean?
o: The OPTIONS request failed (403, 500) or returned wrong headers (e.g. Method not allowed)

q: What does 'No Access-Control-Allow-Origin header is present on the requested resource' mean?
o: Server didn't send the allow header at all. (Standard CORS block)

q: What does 'The value of the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header ... is not equal to the supplied origin' mean?
o: Server sent a header, but it didn't match your Origin (and wasn't *)
Cannot be used if `Allow-Credentials` is true. Cannot be used for `Allow-Headers` or `Allow-Methods` in some older browsers (safest to list)
Not supported by spec. Must list methods (GET, POST, etc.)
Supported in modern browsers (wildcard allowed for headers), but not older ones
AMP imposes strict CORS rules (AMP-Access-Control-Allow-Source-Origin) for dynamic components
AWS S3 buckets are private/no-CORS by default. Must configure CORS XML/JSON policy to serve assets to web apps

q: What happens if S3 CORS is missing for fonts?
o: Browser blocks font loading (usually requires simple GET CORS)
Must configure `gsutil cors set` to allow web access to storage objects via XHR
Edge caches OPTIONS responses. Must whitelist `Origin`, `Access-Control-Request-Method`, etc. in 'Cache Based on Selected Request Headers'

q: What is 'Vary: Origin' importance for CDNs?
o: Ensures CDN caches separate responses for different origins (or for no origin). Prevents serving 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin: A' to Origin B
CSRF: Attack succeeds because browser sends credentials automatically. CORS: Browser blocks legitimate request/response reading. (Opposite goals)

q: Can CORS stop a hacker running a script outside a browser?
o: No. PyCurl/Postman has no concept of prohibited origin
Iframes follow SOP for DOM access (cannot read content of cross-origin iframe). Fetch inside iframe follows CORS relative to iframe origin
Old way to relax SOP between subdomains (both setting `example.com`). Now disabled usually
Secure way to communicate between Cross-Origin windows/iframes (bypassing SOP DOM restrictions)
Verify `event.origin` in receiver. Specify targetOrigin in sender (don't use `*`)
Yes. CORS applies if sending to cross-origin
Cached by (Origin, URL) tuple. (Or just URL?) Usually specific to the resource URL

q: Does Query String affect Preflight Cache?
o: Yes. `?foo=1` is a different URL than `?foo=2`. Preflight cached for one doesn't apply to other unless browser optimizes
SW intercepts fetch. It can synthesize responses (bypass network) but synthesized response must have valid CORS headers if request was cors mode
JS cannot access properties of the response (status is 0, type is opaque). Only useful for caching/media consumption
Yes. Standard image load is practically `no-cors` GET. You see image, but JS can't read pixels (tainted)
Send CORS request WITH credentials. Server must respond `Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true`
Yes! Authorization header is not a cookie. 'Credential' in CORS context specifically means Cookies/TLS Client Cert. Bearer tokens are just custom headers
Yes. But server can reply `Allow-Origin: *` and `Allow-Headers: Authorization`. (Unless browser treats Auth as credential - some confusion here, usually Bearer is fine with *)

q: Wait, does `withCredentials` flag affect Bearer token?
o: No. `withCredentials` controls Cookies. You manually add Bearer token. But wildcard might track `withCredentials = false`
Browsers historically rejected redirects on OPTIONS preflight. Spec updated to allow it, but support varies. Ideally return 200/204
Library (e.g. `cors` package in Express) that handles OPTIONS requests and sets headers automatically
None. Must list each header (e.g. `Link, X-RateLimit-Limit`). `*` support added recently but risky
Often added by AJAX libraries (jQuery). Triggers Preflight (not safelisted). Used to detect AJAX on server
No. But if present, must be allowed in `Access-Control-Allow-Headers`
`null` (in many browsers) or specific file scheme. Be careful allowing `null`
Only contains Scheme, Host, Port. NO path or query params. Protects user privacy
Referer is full URL (unless policy strips it). Origin is just origin. Origin is preferred for security checks

q: Why rely on Origin and not Referer?
o: Referer can be spoofed (historically) or stripped (privacy). Origin is harder to spoof in browser context

q: Does 'localhost' need CORS for remote API?
o: Yes. `localhost` is a different origin than `api.example.com`. API must allow localhost

q: How to proxy in React/Angular CLI?
o: Set `proxy` in `package.json` or config. Forwards local `/api` calls to remote target backend, stripping/changing origin headers
Not by default. You can add `-H 'Origin: ...'`. Server might check it
Not by default (unless configured or browser capture). It ignores CORS response headers anyway
Extensions with host permissions can bypass CORS (background scripts). Content scripts still subject to page CORS
Fake protocol. `cors-anywhere` is a node.js proxy
Adds 1 RTT before actual request. Significant for mobile/high-latency networks. Cache it!
Use Simple Requests (GET/POST simple forms) if possible. Avoid custom headers and `application/json`
Yes. Does not trigger preflight (used for uploads)
Yes, if you add custom headers to it (e.g. `Authorization` or `X-Api-Key`)
Originally W3C Recommendation, now part of Fetch Standard (WHATWG)
Sandboxed iframes `allow-scripts` but not `allow-same-origin`. They send `null` origin
Risky. Attackers can create sandboxed iframes to spoof `null` origin

q: What is 'Public API' CORS best practice?
What is 'Private API' CORS best practice?
o: Reflect Origin if whitelisted. `Allow-Credentials: true`. Do NOT use `*`
Allows any site to read resource timing (waterfall) details. Low security risk typically
No. They are server-side bots, not browsers. They ignore CORS headers
Googlebot generally renders JS now, so it might respect CORS if the rendering engine enforces it, but usually indexing works

q: Can 'Service Worker' bypass CORS for cached assets?
o: No. Opaque responses cached remain opaque. Verify CORS before caching if you need to read it
Library for SW. Has strategies like `CacheFirst`. Can configure to handle opaque responses
Seven headers JS can read without `Expose-Headers`: Cache-Control, Content-Language, Content-Length, Content-Type, Expires, Last-Modified, Pragma

q: Can JS read `Date` header by default?
o: No? Actually `Date` is NOT safelisted in Fetch spec. Requires Expose-Hedaers?
No. Browser forbids exposing `Set-Cookie` (and `Set-Cookie2`) regardless of policy
To prevent JS from stealing Session IDs (HttpOnly concept)
Send origin for HTTPS->HTTPS. Don't send for HTTPS->HTTP. (Use `strict-origin-when-cross-origin` usually)
Send full URL (path+query) to any origin. Privacy leak. Avoid
Yes. Should be read-only metadata check

q: Can you send a body with OPTIONS?
o: Spec allows it, but Preflight OPTIONS body is empty (Browser sends 0 content length)

q: What does server return for OPTIONS body?

o: None? Must be specified. Usually `GET, POST, OPTIONS, PUT, DELETE`
Only safelisted headers. Custom headers must be explicitly allowed

q: What is 'Fetch' API default mode for CORS?
o: `cors` (Requests cross-origin will fail if server doesn't support CORS)
Ensures request is strictly same-origin. Throws error if URL is cross-origin (Prevents accidental leaks)
Mode used for HTML navigation (loading a page). Not typically used manually in fetch
No. XHR infers mode. It attempts CORS if cross-origin. Cannot force 'no-cors' easily like fetch
`integrity='sha256-...'`. Verifies that fetched resource matches hash. Requires CORS if cross-origin!
To verify the hash, browser must read the script content. SOP blocks reading unless CORS is present (even for scripts)
Browser refuses to execute the script/style

q: What is 'Module Script' (`<script type=module>`) CORS default?
o: Modules are 'defer' by default and REQUIRE CORS for cross-origin loading (unlike classic scripts)

q: Can you load a Module Script without CORS headers from CDN?
o: No. It fails. (Classic scripts work without headers, Modules do not)
ES Modules loaded via `import` must support CORS if cross-origin
Function name passed in URL (`?callback=foo`). Server wraps JSON in `foo({...})`
Yes (GET only). Cannot send data via POST body
5 seconds (Browser default). Hence Preflights happen often if not set

q: How to handle CORS in Node.js (Express)?
How to handle CORS in Python (Flask)?
How to handle CORS in Go?
o: Use a middleware handler (e.g. `rs/cors`) to intercept OPTIONS and add headers

q: How to handle CORS in Nginx?
o: Add `add_header` directives. Handle `if ($request_method = OPTIONS) { return 204; }` manually
Redirects during preflight were forbidden. Now allowed, but browser must check CORS on redirect target too
Reading `Location` header in JS requires exposing it. But browser usually handles redirect transparency
Yes. `null` != `null`. But for string matching in CORS header, `null` is the literal string
No. The header must be a single string (literal origin or *). Logic to match regex must happen on Server script
Front-end calling multiple microservices on different subdomains requires CORS on each service

q: What is 'API Gateway' role in CORS?
o: Gateway provides single origin (stops CORS issues) or handles CORS centrally for all backend services
Nginx/HAProxy serves frontend and api on same domain (`/` and `/api`), eliminating CORS need completely
Maybe. If attacker switches DNS IP from evil to localhost mid-session, they might access localhost. Browsers pin DNS to prevent this
New security feature. Websites on public internet cannot access private IPs (RFC 1918) without explicit Permission (Preflight)
Client sends this in preflight to private IP. Server must reply `Access-Control-Allow-Private-Network: true`

q: Does `127.0.0.1` need Private Network Access check?
o: Yes. It is considered private. Public `example.com` trying to hit `127.0.0.1:8080` triggers mixed-content/PNA checks
HTTPS page loading HTTP resource. Active content (scripts) blocked. Passive (images) warning
No. Mixed Content block happens before CORS. You cannot load HTTP API from HTTPS page even with CORS

q: How to fix Mixed Content locally?
o: Run local dev server with HTTPS (mkcert) or use proxy
Tool to create locally trusted development certificates (Simplifies local HTTPS/CORS dev)
Tunneling tool. Exposes local port to public HTTPS URL. Helps test CORS/Webhooks
Not automatically. Your local server must still handle headers, but ngrok provides HTTPS origin to avoid Mixed Content
Cookies have 'Domain' and 'Path' attributes, not strict Origin (Port ignored for cookies!). Different from DOM SOP
Yes! Cookie scope is Domain. Ports do not isolate cookies (security quirk)

q: Do you need CORS for Cookies?
o: CORS with credentials allows Ssending/Reading cookies on Cross-Origin XHR. Without it, cookies aren't sent
Browsers blocking cookies from different origins (tracking protection). Breaks 'CORS with Credentials' flows often
API to request permission to access third-party cookies (e.g. for embeds) when blocked by default
Fonts loaded via `@font-face` MUST undergo CORS check if cross-origin. (Standard mandates it)
Generally No (`<link rel=stylesheet>`). But accessing CSSOM (rules) might be blocked if cross-origin
Requests CSS with CORS. Allows reading CSSMain via JS without security error
Yes. Cross-origin images cannot be used as textures unless CORS approved
JS property to request image with CORS (must be set BEFORE src)

q: What if server doesn't support CORS for image?
o: Image might fail to load entirely if `crossOrigin` is set
Same as Image. Need `crossorigin` to capture frame to canvas or access data
Fetching segments for MSE (DASH/HLS) uses XHR/Fetch, so MUST follow CORS
m3u8 playlist and ts segments must have CORS headers if hosted on CDN
PDF viewer (pdf.js) fetching PDF via XHR needs CORS
Unrelated. XFO controls iframing (Clickjacking). CORS controls data access
Modern replacement for X-Frame-Options. Controls who can embed you
Header Names are case-insensitive. Values (Origins) are case-sensitive!
Yes. Trailing slash in path doesn't change origin
International domains (`xn--...`). Browser converts to punycode for Origin check. Server needs to handle punycode string
List of domains where users can register subdomains (co.uk, github.io). Affects Cookie security and potentially Origin trust concepts
No. `*.example.com` is not in spec (though some frameworks support config). Spec requires full match or `*`
Max redirects (0 allowed historically, now some). Max age (limited by browser)
Reflecting any origin allows any site to attack users (CSRF-like via CORS). Must validate against whitelist
Present on Cross-Origin requests. Present on Same-Origin POST/PUT (in modern browsers, to prevent CSRF). Missing on Same-Origin GET usually
Yes. `curl -H 'Origin: http://evil.com'`. Server must not trust it blindly for auth, but used for CORS logic
Header indicating relationship (`same-origin`, `cross-site`, `none`). More reliable than Origin for server checks
Header indicating destination (`document`, `image`, `script`). Helps server decide security policy
No. Forbidden headers. Set by browser. Reliable for server-side security logic
No. Spec requires it. Use `text/plain` if you really must skip it (but you lose JSON parsing auto)
Config used in dev to proxy requests to backend to avoid CORS
No! Setup is dev-server only. In prod, you must serve app from same origin or configure CORS on backend
Common error. Server not configured to handle OPTIONS method (API only handles GET/POST)
Error. Preflight should not require Auth (Browser doesn't send creds in Preflight usually). Open OPTIONS to public
No. OPTIONS request is stripped of Cookies/Auth headers by browser
Safe for public/read-only APIs. Dangerous for internal/private APIs
JSONP is faster (no preflight). CORS is safer and more capable

q: Can you wrap CORS in Promise?
o: CORS is handled by fetch/xhr which return Promises (or callbacks). You don't wrap CORS itself
Browser asking permission to send Authorization header
No? Simple requests don't preflight, so they don't see this header until response. But server might block method anyway

q: What is `Link` header impact on CORS?
o: Exposed headers must include `Link` if client needs to read pagination links from header
Controls which origins the script can connect to (XHR, Fetch, WebSocket). Separate from CORS check (both must pass)

q: If CSP blocks origin X, is CORS Preflight sent?
o: No. CSP check usually happens before network request is dispatched. (Browser console shows CSP violation)
Cross-Origin Embedder Policy. Forces document to only load resources that explicitly grant permission via CORP or CORS
Resource loads only from same origin. Blocks cross-origin loading even if they try. Good for sensitive JSON
Resource allows being embedded by any origin (like CORS * but for embedding, not reading data?)
Isolates browsing context. `window.opener` becomes null for cross-origin popups. Prevents XS-Leaks/Spectre
Yes, if they need `window.opener` to communicate back. Unless `same-origin-allow-popups` is used or OAuth flow uses redirects
Environment state when `COOP: same-origin` and `COEP: require-corp` are set. Unlocks `SharedArrayBuffer`
Spectre vulnerability (timing attacks via precise shared memory clocks). Re-enabled only with COOP/COEP isolation
Cross-Site Leak.Side-channel attack guessing state of user on another site (e.g. search results count) via timing/frames
It generally prevents reading data directly. But timing attacks (search duration) might bypass CORS reading protections
Prevent malicious public website from scanning internal network (port scanning localhost) via image loops or XHR timing

q: Can you port-scan localhost via Browser?
o: Historically yes (timing attack on error responses). PNA (Private Network Access) aims to block this
Complex Vary header. Tells cache to vary on both Origin and the requested Method (for Preflight caching)

q: What is 'CORS' response on `304 Not Modified`?
o: Must still include CORS headers! If cache revalidates and returns 304 without CORS headers, browser triggers CORS error

q: Does server need to handle OPTIONS for every endpoint?
o: If enabling CORS globally, yes. Middleware usually handles `*` route for OPTIONS
Rules are strict. `Header-A, Header-B` (no internal spaces is safer? or space after comma). Follow spec

q: What is 'Origin' header on `POST` to same origin?
o: Browsers send it. Server can use it to verify request is not CSRF (Origin matches Host). 'Origin-based anti-CSRF'
No. Origin might be missing (some privacy modes?). Tokens are more robust. But Origin check is a good defense-in-depth
Request comes from a completely different site (e.g. evil.com to bank.com). Risky
Request comes from same origin. Usually trusted
Request from same 'site' (eTlD+1) but maybe different subdomain/port/scheme. (e.g. auth.example.com to api.example.com)
User-initiated (e.g. typing URL in bar, bookmark). Start of navigation
Resource Isolation Policy. Block requests where `Sec-Fetch-Site` is `cross-site` unless it's a known safe endpoint (public API)
Generally No (browser fetches it). But if JS fetches it via Image/XHR, yes
Yes. Must be served with CORS headers if on CDN (Cross-Origin)
Yes. `new Worker('http://other.com/worker.js')` is Cross-Origin. Needs CORS
0 bytes (exposed to JS). Actual footprint in browser memory exists but hidden from JS logic
Browser prompts for credentials? No, AJAX with Basic Auth needs `withCredentials` or explicit `Authorization` header
No. Origin is Scheme+Host+Port. URL path/query/hash are irrelevant for Origin definition
Yes. `blob:` URLs inherit origin of the context that created them. (e.g. blob:https://example.com/...)

q: Can you CORS fetch a `blob:` URL?
o: Usually treat as Same-Origin if created by same page. Cross-origin access to blob URL is blocked (UUID is unique)
Treated as unique opaque origin (process dependent). Often `null` or unique. Cross-origin by default relative to page
Inherits origin of the document that opened it (or into which it is embedded if iframe)
Inherits origin of the document where it executes
No strict order required. But usually `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` first
No! RFC says MUST be single header with single value. (Some servers send two lines, browsers might reject or pick first)
If client sends `Content-Type: application/json`, it is a requested header. Server must allow it in `Access-Control-Allow-Headers`
Yes. `Access-Control-Allow-Origins` (plural) is a common mistake. It is Singular `Origin`
Yes. It is a single value (seconds)

q: What if Preflight succeeds but actual request fails CORS?
o: Possible. Preflight checks Permission. Actual request might have dynamic logic that fails (e.g. DB error) or returns different headers

q: What if Actual Request omits CORS headers?
o: Browser blocks response reading (even if Preflight passed). Every response in CORS chain must have headers
Yes! If the original request used credentials. Missing header on 304 causes CORS error
Yes, if exposed. Useful for caching
None standard. Some frameworks add `X-CORS-Debug` info
Exposes ALL headers (except Set-Cookie). Supported in newer specs/browsers
The Browser (User Agent). The Server just provides permission slips (headers)
Server can check `Origin` and block request (403). But standard CORS flow is Browser blocking Response Reading
No. Origin uses Domain names. IP is network layer. Though `http://1.2.3.4` is a valid origin
Yes, if 80 is default for http. Normalization happens

q: What is 'Origin' of a generic file drag-and-drop?
o: Files read via FileReader (File API) from user disk don't really have an origin in the HTTP sense? `null` or context origin
Firewall can inspect HTTP headers and block specific Origins. Defense in depth
Yes! You will see OPTIONS requests in access logs. Can fill up logs if not cached
Yes. Config server to log OPTIONS to /dev/null or separate file (common practice)
Depends on API Gateway. Some charge for every call (including OPTIONS). Some ignore it. Check pricing!
Must configure API Gateway to header CORS or return CORS headers from Lambda function code
Lambda responsbile for returning headers: `{ headers: { 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*' } }`
XML/JSON config on bucket. Define allowed origins and methods
GitHub Pages sends `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *` for all static assets by default (usually)
CDN must forward OPTIONS to origin OR handle them at edge. Must respect Vary header
Handling CORS logic in Edge function (Cloudflare Workers, Lambda@Edge). Fast, dynamic, no hit to origin
Sending two `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` headers usually breaks the browser parser. Don't append, replace
Yes. WebDAV methods (PROPFIND, MKCOL) are HTTP methods. Need Preflight and `Allow-Methods`
GraphQL usually uses POST `application/json`. Triggers Preflight. Server must handle OPTIONS
Not for peer connection itself (UDP/TCP). But signaling server (WebSocket/HTTP) needs CORS. `getUserMedia` permissions are separate
Successor to CORB. HEURISTICALLY blocks opaque cross-origin responses from entering renderer process if they look like HTML/XML/JSON
Controls which browser features (camera, mic, geolocation) are allowed in document and IFRAMES. Can block features cross-origin
Yes! You can disable synchronous XHR to improve performance/UX
`WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming` requires the WASM file to be served with correct MIME (`application/wasm`) AND CORS if cross-origin

q: What happens if WASM has wrong MIME?

o: If server returns ACAO based on Origin header but forgets Vary: Origin, ISP proxies might cache response for User A (Origin X) and serve to User B (Origin Y), causing CORS error for B
Good way to test server headers manually. `-I` (head) might be wrong if OPTIONS has body, but usually works for checking standard headers
Yes. If import map JSON is fetched cross-origin, it needs CORS
If developer manually checks `withCredentials` on client but forgets server uses `*`, browser blocks it safely. But if server hardcodes `Allow-Credentials: true` with `*`, browser enforces block
If Preflight returns 404/400, browser treats it as Failure. Actual request is NOT sent

q: Can you define CORS headers in meta tag?
o: No. CORS headers MUST be HTTP headers. `<meta http-equiv=...>` does not support CORS headers
Security checks happen before HTML parsing (often). Headers are safer/earlier

q: What is 'Samesite=Strict' cookie interaction with CORS?
o: Strict cookies are NOT sent on top-level navigation from other sites, nor cross-site subrequests. CORS credentials relies on cookie presence
Modern browsers default to Lax. Cookies not sent on cross-site subrequests (images/xhr) unless user navigates. Breaks 'default' CORS auth without `SameSite=None; Secure`

q: How to fix CORS Auth with SameSite in modern browsers?
o: Set cookie `SameSite=None; Secure`. Allows sending cookie on cross-site CORS request (with `withCredentials`)
`SameSite=None` REQUIRED `Secure` (HTTPS). You cannot have cross-site cookies on HTTP anymore
If site accepts HTTP (no HSTS), attacker injects script. Script makes CORS requests to internal/local services. (Local Network Access reduces this)
Attacker uses `data:` or `sandbox` iframe to generate request from `null` origin. If server whitelists `null`, they bypass SOP
Almost never. Maybe for local file development, but highly discouraged in production
Measuring how long a cross-origin request takes (even if blocked) to guess if user is logged in (redirect vs direct, database cache hit)
Make responses constant time? Hard. Use COOP/COEP to reduce timer precision. Or SameSite cookies to prevent auth'd state usage
Exposes redirect start/end times. Blocked/Zeroed out for cross-origin unless `Timing-Allow-Origin` is present
Spec requires it to prevent font piracy (licensing). Browsers respect this DRM-like feature via CORS
Some fonts are scrambled and unlocked by JS. CORS ensures only authorized domains fetch the font blob
Fetching SVG via `` is simple GET. Fetching via XHR (to inject into DOM) needs CORS
If canvas is tainted (drew cors-less image), `toDataURL` returns exception/security error. Prevents pixel scraping
You cannot untaint it. You must start fresh with CORS-enabled images (`crossOrigin='anonymous'`)
Indirectly. If cache holds a response without CORS headers and valid for days, subsequent CORS requests failing is a 'Cache Poisoning' issue (Solve with Vary: Origin)
Browser cache. Less risk of cross-user poisoning than CDN (Shared) cache
Proxy/CDN. HIGH risk of serving wrong CORS headers to wrong origin if Vary is missing
CORS is Access Control (Authorization-ish). Auth is Login. CORS does not identify WHO you are, only WHERE you are from
Common modern pattern. Token in header. Requires Preflight. CORS * allowed (usually). No cookie issues
Legacy/Standard pattern. Cookie implicit. Requires `withCredentials`. `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` CANNOT be *. Vulnerable to CSRF if not careful
You trust the code served from that Origin. CORS allows that trusted code to talk to your API

q: Can a malicious browser lie about Origin?
o: Yes. You cannot trust Origin header for strictly authenticating a device. You trust it to differentiate honest users browsing site A vs site B
Not a thing? Maybe typo for CORS-Everywhere extension?
Public proxy. If you use it for production, your data passes through third-party server. Privacy nightmare. Rate limits

q: Can you host your own 'CORS Anywhere'?
o: Yes. `npm install cors-anywhere`. Run on your own Heroku/VPS. Safer for dev proxies

q: What is 'Reverse Proxy' vs CORS Proxy?
o: Reverse proxy (Nginx) makes it Same-Origin (client sees one domain). CORS proxy adds headers to Cross-Origin response. Reverse proxy is architectural fix
No. Headers logic is same. Though HPACK compresses verbose CORS headers efficiently
No. Semantics are identical. Transport is UDP but Browser security model remains
Web Application Firewall. Can filter/block requests with bad Origins before they hit app. Can inject CORS headers too
API Key identifies Project/Client. Origin identifies serving domain. Use both for defense

q: Can you restrict API Key by Referer/Origin?
o: Yes. Google Maps API keys do this. They check Referer header to prevent key theft usage
Using tools outside browser to send fake Referer. Browsers generally protect Referer. Extension can change it
UA is irrelevant for CORS logic technically, but servers might vary logic based on UA (e.g. mobile app vs browser)
Uploading file via XHR/Fetch (FormData) triggers Preflight if Cross-Origin. Simple POST (form submit) might not read response
Resumable upload. Uses PATCH/HEAD methods. REQUIRES CORS Preflight configuration for custom methods
PATCH is NOT a simple method. Always triggers Preflight
HEAD is simple method (like GET). No Preflight (unless custom headers)
PUT is NOT simple. Triggers Preflight
DELETE is NOT simple. Triggers Preflight
Old exploit. Flash had `crossdomain.xml`. Dead now
Some PDF readers had vulnerabilities making cross-origin requests. Browsers sandbox them heavily now
Unrelated. CT is SSL trust. CORS is browser access control
It is invisible (happens in browser network layer), errors are vague (security), and caching makes it flaky
Setup two local servers (port 3000, 4000). Try fetching. Watch Network tab. Fix errors
No! React Native uses native networking, not browser engine. No SOP. CORS irrelevant (unless using WebView)
Yes, if using Renderer process normally. But can disable `webSecurity` in BrowserWindow preference (careful!)
If using native HTTP plugin, No. If using standard `fetch` in WebView, Yes (and origin is usually `capacitor://localhost` or similar)
`capacitor://localhost` (iOS) or `http://localhost` (Android). API must whitelist this scheme/origin
Not valid standard value. Must typically use `null` for file or `*`? Browser support for file scheme CORS is inconsistent
For Iframe communication: Yes. For Server communication: No
No. TLS verifies connection. Origin header is trusted because TLS prevents tampering
No. It is a cooperating mechanism between Browser and Server. It does not stop non-browser traffic
Same-Origin: Scheme+Host+Port (Strict). Same-Site: eTLD+1 (Looser, used for Cookies)

q: Which is safer: SOP or SameSite?
o: SOP is the bedrock of web security boundaries. SameSite is a cookie attribute amendment
Yes. Service Worker intercepts requests. If fetching from external API, CORS still applies
